comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: C. 1910: I hadn't realised the defilement of our built heritage with pebbledash had set in that long ago.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Signs on doorway to left of car read BSA Bicycles. According to Wikipedia, BSA made bicycles from 1880 to 1887, and then again from 1908 onwards. So given the car there, this would be after 1908.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Given the history of Mountmellick as a Quaker town, (and I've lots of Quaker ancestors who lived there, or nearby), is that woman on the left of frame wearing some sort of traditional Quaker dress?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] 1910 is speculative date based on Eason Collection photos being taken between 1900 and 1939; clothing, etc. Absolutely willing to be persuaded otherwise!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Ah, could that be it? As haven't really seen quite that rig-out in many of our photos before.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I do not see H. Smith or sons in the census of 1901 or 1911. Humphrey Smith is in the 1931 trade directory. A shot of Smith's shopfront with the awning stowed.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Curiouser and curiouser! Any sign of a pawnbroker?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Could this be a case of a business retaining its name after the demise of its founder (like, um, W H Smith)? A Humphrey Smith is mentioned here being active in Mountmellick in the 19th century.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A Humphrey Smith of Mountmellick was married in 1850. Perhaps the shop was being run by someone not named Smith by the time of the picture? (Great minds! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] )

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Patrick Talbot Malone, Draper and Pawnbroker

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] And Bidelia Malone - fantastic name! But 8 children, only 4 of whom were alive.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Mr. Malone was a pawnbroker in 1901 and 1911.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Rather than the ebay offering, the Pratts sign looks more like this one at Beamish with the car in the corner

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: A BSA sign very similar to H. Smith & Sons BSA sign

comment.author: 30369211@N00
64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I should be doing other things today, but was having a quick search for Quaker clothing, or "Plain Dress" to give it it's proper name. Found a link to a site with some photos of early 20th century plain dress. And that same site's owner, has a photo of herself wearing a bonnet quite similar to the lady in Mountmellick. More photos here too. Given the age of the woman in the photo, and given Mountmellick's heritage as a Quaker town, I'd think is is an elderly, plain dressing Quaker. Christopher Moriarty at the Friends Library in Rathfarnham might have more info.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Great suggestion! I just emailed Christopher Moriarty, so we'll await developments...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content:
It is striking how well maintained the buildings on this street are espically when contrasted with recent street phots you have shared..
Either a prosperous time in general or an upmarket part of town.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Several of these buildings are in the National Inventory of Architectural Heritage.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward/] So, this must be after 1876 when Symes' plans were signed and dated, but wonder when it was actually built?

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: Photo from different angle (different day):

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Unusually for a professional photographer (Eason), but the verticals have not been corrected for convergence. Either that or there is serious subsidence on the right.

comment.author: 22296698@N05
comment._content: My home town. Cracking photo. Called the "Manchester of Ireland" for it's industry and commerce. Most retailers shown now well gone and/or changed hands. That turn at the bank is still known as Smiths Corner. I must check with family if they know of Quakers dressing like that. I wonder if this is a nun from the Presentation Sisters school close by ! Good history of the college here www.presentation-sisters.ie/content/view/100/125/

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: If this was a stereoview the change in angle on the second image might just reveal that number plate ...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There is a similar looking car in this Mountmellick shot in the archive.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Well spotted, Mr! That registration no. is LN 3844.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Not an Irish reg, then, all Irish regs had an I or a Z in them. From wikipedia: When a licensing authority reached 9999, it was allocated another two-letter code, but there was no pattern to these subsequent allocations as they were allocated on a first come first served basis. London and Middlesex quickly took most codes with L and M as the first letter respectively So, perhaps a London registration?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Yes, London. From this page, it's LN NOV 1906 -> MAR 1908

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] So, circa 1910 not wildly astray for this one then?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Sounds about right. The car must have been registered in 1907, so that's the earliest possible year, but 1910 seems likely enough. I see a few references online to those nectar Tea signs being c.1910, made from 1905 to 1915.
